misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem (road trip cost) instead of number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The submitted program calculates the cost of a road trip using distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of implementing the required number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user guesses until correct.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this question requires a road trip cost calculator (or they accidentally submitted code for a different question) rather than a number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should implement a number guessing game: use Random to generate an integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess, after each incorrect guess print either "Too high" or "Too low", and terminate when the guess is correct, reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of asking for number guesses.
No Random object is created and no secret answer in the range 1–100 is generated.
No loop to allow multiple guesses; input is read only three times for numeric values unrelated to guessing.
No conditional logic that compares a guess to a secret number or prints "Too high" / "Too low".
No termination condition based on a correct guess or reporting of the number of guesses.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or a submission mix-up: the student reused or submitted a solution from a separate "road trip cost" problem instead of implementing the specified guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or save this road trip cost code for its appropriate question and re-read the Q2 specification carefully. Design a new main method that (1) creates a Random object and generates an int between 1 and 100, (2) uses a loop to read user guesses, (3) uses if/else to print "Too high" or "Too low" after wrong guesses, and (4) stops when the guess equals the secret number and reports the number of attempts.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to program structure
Basic use of Random and loops for interactive programs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every prompt and calculation in the submitted code is about driving distance and fuel cost, with no partial or incorrect attempt at any aspect of a number guessing game, indicating the entire program targets a different problem.

evidence.note: Main method implements a road trip cost calculator with distance, mpg, and price inputs; there is no Random, no guessing loop, and no high/low feedback as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Irrelevant Submission / Failure to Address Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (Road Trip Cost calculation) and did not attempt the required Number Guessing Game. The submission therefore lacks implementation of all required concepts: random number generation, iterative input loops, and conditional logic for feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted a solution from a previous or different assignment, believing it satisfied the current requirement, or simply submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement a Number Guessing Game using the Java Random class, iterative input (loops), and conditional statements (if/else) to provide hints.
symptoms: No loops or random number generation are present
No 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Submitting the wrong file, or misunderstanding the assignment context/requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please delete this content and write a program that uses the Random class to pick a secret number, and a while loop with if/else statements to process user guesses and give high/low hints.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's functionality (calculating road trip costs) is diametrically opposed to the problem statement (implementing a number guessing game).

evidence.note: The class name indicates the program's purpose is related to cost calculation, not game playing.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("Enter the driving distance in miles: ");
evidence.note: The program prompts for inputs entirely unrelated to a number guessing game.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The cost of driving is $%f", (distance / mpg) * price);
evidence.note: The core logic performs arithmetic for cost calculation, lacking any game logic, loops, or conditional feedback.

misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem instead of the number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes the cost of a road trip (distance / mpg * price) instead of implementing the required number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user repeatedly guesses until correct with "Too high"/"Too low" hints.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for driving distance, fuel efficiency, and fuel price, then outputs the driving cost; this will satisfy the requirements for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, you must implement the specified number guessing game: generate a random integer in [1, 100], repeatedly prompt the user for guesses, compare each guess to the secret number, print "Too high" or "Too low" for incorrect guesses, count the number of guesses, and terminate only when the user guesses correctly, then report the guess count.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of guesses.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop structure to allow repeated guessing.
No conditional logic comparing a guess to a secret number or printing "Too high" / "Too low".
Program performs a single arithmetic calculation and terminates, so it cannot behave as a guessing game.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the problem statement or mixing up this question with a different exercise (e.g., a textbook road trip cost problem), leading to implementing the wrong algorithm for the given prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and list the required behaviors: (1) generate a random int between 1 and 100, (2) use a loop to read guesses until correct, (3) inside the loop, compare the guess to the secret and print "Too high" or "Too low", and (4) keep a counter of guesses and print it when the guess is correct. Then design and code directly from that list, checking that each rubric item is present in your program.
related_concepts: Reading and translating specifications into code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure and prompts of the program match a standard "road trip cost" exercise and contain none of the required elements (Random, guessing loop, high/low hints), so it is very unlikely this was an attempt at a number guessing game with minor mistakes.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating road trip cost; it never generates a random number, never prompts for guesses, has no loop, and has no conditional logic for "Too high" or "Too low" hints as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Submitted code for the wrong problem (Road Trip Cost)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates road trip cost instead of implementing the requested Number Guessing Game. Consequently, none of the required game logic (random number generation, looping, conditional hints) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe this solution is appropriate for the assignment, or they submitted the wrong file entirely, failing to address the problem requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted file must contain code that solves the specific problem statement provided: creating a Number Guessing Game.
symptoms: The code calculates cost, not managing a guessing game loop
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding assignment requirements, submitting the wrong file, or confusing questions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and ensure the submitted code directly addresses all required parts of the Number Guessing Game (random number generation, input loop, comparison logic).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously solving a different, unrelated problem.

evidence.note: Class name immediately indicates the student is solving the wrong problem.
Input requested is for road trip calculation, not number guessing.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The cost of driving is $%f", (distance / mpg) * price);
evidence.note: Final output is the computed driving cost, confirming the code is unrelated to the guessing game.
